title: Stadionul CFR (Timișoara)
text:
CFR Stadium () is a <a href="multi-purpose%20stadium">multi-purpose stadium</a> in <a href="Timi%C8%99oara">Timișoara</a>, <a href="Romania">Romania</a>. It is currently used mostly for <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> matches and is the home ground of <a href="CFR%20Timi%C8%99oara">CFR Timișoara</a>. The stadium holds 7,000 people.
It was also the home ground of <a href="Chinezul%20Timi%C8%99oara">Chinezul Timișoara</a> and <a href="CA%20Timi%C8%99oara">CA Timișoara</a>, which was named Stadionul Banatul at that time.
History.
Inaugurated in 1913, the Banatul Stadium occupied the land of the current stadium until <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. In 1944, the stadium was destroyed by <a href="Strategic%20bombing%20during%20World%20War%20II">Allied bombings</a>, which also destroyed the neighboring <a href="Timi%C8%99oara%20North%20railway%20station">Domnița Elena railway station</a>. A new stadium was rebuilt by <a href="CSF%20CFR%20Timi%C8%99oara">CFR</a> employees five years later. It was officially inaugurated on 17 October 1949, on the occasion of a <a href="Exhibition%20game">friendly match</a> between <a href="CSF%20CFR%20Timi%C8%99oara">CFR Timisoara</a> and MATEOSz Budapest. Until 1964, in the opening of football games, <a href="rugby%20football">rugby</a> was played here.
In 2020, during the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, the authorities built a <a href="field%20hospital">modular hospital</a> here, as a section of the Military Hospital, intended exclusively for the treatment of <a href="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> patients. In 2021, the stadium hosted an eight-day <a href="COVID-19%20vaccine">COVID-19 vaccination</a> marathon.
